Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: I was texting Mia, my girlfriend, about which evening we should spend together this week. She wanted us to pick a night to finally have that long, uninterrupted dinner we’d been talking about. I promised her I’d make time, that I’d be present, not distracted by work or my phone. As I was about to suggest Thursday, the bell above the salon door chimed. A woman stepped in, clutching her bag, eyes darting around the room. She looked lost, maybe even a little scared. I knew that look—first-time nerves. As a hairdresser, it was my job to greet her warmly, help her feel at ease, and show her she was in good hands. But my phone buzzed again—Mia, asking if I’d decided. I felt the pressure mounting: Mia deserved my attention, but so did this client. I stood there, phone in hand, heart tugged in two directions, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed at the same time.
